tit.e: Kangofu (a tally or a trading license)
tit.cmt: タイトルなので補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 勘合符(かんごうふ)は日明貿易等に用いられた、明と朝貢国間の正式の来貢、通交船であることを証明する明が発行した割符。
sen.e: Kangofu was a tally or a trading license issued by the Ming dynasty and used in trades, such as the Ming-Japanese trade, to confirm authorized tribute and trade ships between the Ming dynasty and a tributary state.

A kangofu was a tally or trading license issued by the Ming dynasty and used in trade, such as the Ming-Japanese trade, to confirm authorized tribute and trade ships between the Ming dynasty and a tributary state.

sen.j: 勘合符は東アジアの50ヶ国程度に与えられた。
sen.e: Kangofu was issued in about fifty countries of Southeast Asia.

sen.cmt: アラビア数字にしました。

sen.j: 勘合符の主な目的は、朝貢国と明との国家間の位置づけを明確にすること(中華思想)と公私船の区別を行うことである。
sen.e: The main purposes of Kangofu were to clarify the position between a tributary state and the Ming dynasty (Sinocentrism) and to distinguish official ships from private ones.

sen.j: 当時の私船(民間貿易)は、倭寇に代表される手荒い貿易方法で、元 (王朝)の衰退を惹起させる程のもので看過できないものであった。
sen.e: The private ships in those days (private foreign trade) as typified in Wako (Japanese pirates) carried out trade in such a rough way that it caused a decline in the Yuan dynasty and that it could not be overlooked.

The private ships in those days (partaking in private foreign trade) as typified by the wako (Japanese pirates) carried out trade in such a rough way that it caused a weakening of the Yuan dynasty which could not be overlooked.

sen.j: 明は日本(幕府)に倭寇の取り締まりを求め、幕府も公船で貿易を行ない、私貿易を禁止すれば、既存の民間貿易の利得を幕府側で一手に引き受けることが可能になるという目論見から、勘合符を用いる貿易が推し進められることとなった。
sen.e: As the Ming dynasty required Japan (bakufu, the shogunate) to crack down on Wako, the bakufu carried on trade by official ships and prohibited private foreign trade in the hope that the bakufu could exercise total control over existing profits from private foreign trade; thus, the trade by using Kangofu was implemented.

As the Ming dynasty required Japan (that is, the bakufu, the shogunate) to crack down on the wako, the bakufu continued to trade using official ships and prohibited private foreign trade in the hope that they could exercise total control over existing profits from private foreign trade; thus, trade using Kangofu was implemented.
sen.cmt: Grammar, word choice, punctuation. Having 民間貿易 and 私貿易 both as "private foreign trade" is confusing, but I am not sure of the difference: perhaps 民間貿易 could be translated as "government controlled private foreign trade". Please check.
sen.e: As the Ming dynasty required Japan (that is, the bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun]) to crack down on the wako, the bakufu continued to trade using official ships and prohibited private foreign trade in the hope that they could exercise total control over existing profits from private foreign trade; thus, trade using Kangofu was implemented.

sen.j: 明、朝貢国の双方が、勘合符と勘合底簿を持ち合う。
sen.e: Both the Ming dynasty and the tributary state possessed Kangofu and Kango teibo (matching seals on a sheet of paper divided into two: one is called Kangofu and the other called Kango teibo or a registration book).

sen.j: 日明間では、日字勘合(日字号勘合)と本字勘合があり、本字勘合(百道：本字一号～百号)を日本の遣明船が明の港(寧波)に持参し、明の所有する本字勘合底簿と照合する。
sen.e: Between Japan and the Ming dynasty, Nichiji Kango or Nichijigo Kango (a tally or a trading license with the Japanese letter of "nichi 日") and Honji Kango (a tally or a trading license with the Japanese letter of "hon 本") were used; Honji Kango (one hundred copies: Honji No.1 - No. 100) was brought by the Japanese envoy ship to the seaport in Ming (Ningbo), and compared with Honji Kango teibo (a registration book) that the Ming dynasty possessed.

sen.j: 遣明船は本字号勘合を1号から順次持参し，浙江の布政司(行政府)と北京の礼部で底簿と照合される。
sen.e: The Japanese envoy ship dispatched to Ming China brought Honjigo Kango in order from No.1, and they were compared with Honji Kango teibo in the executive office in Zhejiang and the Ministry of Civil Administration in Beijing.

sen.j: 勘合符の実物は残されていないが、禅僧の天与清啓が明への渡航を記録した「戊子入明記」に「本字壱号」（本字壹號）の勘合符の例図が描かれている。
sen.e: The real Kangofu was not preserved; however, "the Boshi Nyuminki" (The Account of the visit to Ming in 1468), a Zen priest Tenyo Seikei's travel report to Ming, included the illustration of "Honji Ichigo" (Honji No. 1).

sen.j: 基本的には、朱墨の半印がされた文字と、筆記の漢数字(一方は朱：赤で記載)のある大きめの縦長(縦：82cm 横：36cm)の紙で、裏面には献上物、数、付帯貨物、正使以下の乗船者数などを記入したもの。
sen.e: Basically, Kangofu was a tall sheet of paper larger in size (82 cm long by 36 cm broad) on which matching seals of letters in red and black ink and Chinese kanji numbers in handwriting (either of the numbers was written in red ink) were printed, and on the other side of which articles for presentation, the number of articles, supplementary cargos, and the number of passengers including a chief delegate were listed.

Basically, the Kangofu was a long sheet of paper, large in size (82 cm long by 36 cm across), on which the matching seals with letters in red and black ink and handwritten Chinese kanji numbers (one of which was written in red ink) were printed, and on the other side of the document the type and number of articles for presentation, supplementary cargo, the number of passengers and the chief delegate were listed.
